awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Van der Waals-mediated epitaxy of Heusler compounds through properties-selective, atomically thin barriers
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical summary
 
Modern electronics rely on precisely controlled interfaces between crystalline semiconducting materials. Achieving this remains a challenge. This project, supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program in the Division of Materials Research, researches fundamentally new ways to fabricate such interfaces of magnetic materials and control them at the smallest length scale possible (atomic resolution). Focusing on a class of materials called Heusler compounds, the project explores the mechanisms for single-crystalline growth on atomically thin barrier materials. Application of these materials in energy-efficient magnetic and thermoelectric devices is also tested. The research efforts are integrated with an after-school workshop for middle-school students. "From atoms to iPhone: the science of materials and their applications in everyday life." is a workshop that engages young students in materials science and engineering topics through the lens of a common application, the smartphone. The principle investigator and his group carry out work with the SCIENCountErs program at the Boys and Girls Club of Dane County on this. 

Technical summary

This project is supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program in the Division of Materials Research and aims to uncover and develop fundamentally new ways to control the transmission of ions, charge, and spins across Heusler interfaces. Heusler compounds have long been proposed as ideal materials for semiconductor spintronics and a platform for discovery and manipulation of topological quantum states of matter. However, interdiffusion across the Heusler/semiconductor interface has inhibited these realizations, since atomically sharp and stable epitaxial interfaces are required. This project addresses these challenges through the use atomically thin barrier materials such as graphene, where the barrier material serves as (1) a diffusion barrier, (2) a transparent decoupling layer for epitaxial alignment between film and substrate, and (3) a tunnel barrier for efficient charge and spin transport across the interface. By pairing highly controlled Heusler synthesis by molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) with in-situ spectroscopic tools, model experiments are being used to reveal the mechanisms for Van der Waals-mediated epitaxy and develop methods for the atomically controlled fabrication of Heusler interfaces. Fundamental insights from the research component are integrated into real life demonstrations for the "Atoms to iPhone" workshop and integrated into undergraduate and graduate courses taught by the principle investigator. First hand research experiences for undergraduate and graduate students provide a training ground for careers in STEM and related fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit. This project elucidated the fundamental synthesis mechanisms for remote epitaxy and demonstrated new applications for (1) inducing magnetism and via extreme strain in free-standing membranes and (2) stabilizing interfaces between chemically incompatible materials. In remote epitaxy, single crystalline films are grown on a substrate that is covered with an atomically thin material like graphene, where the film adopts the same crystal structure and orientation as the underlying substrate. The "remote" mechanism argues that this epitaxial relationship occurs via the "remote" lattice potential permeation of the substrate through graphene. Using in-situ spectroscopy and microscopy measurements, we showed that pinhole-seeded lateral epitaxy provides an alternative explanation (S. Manzo, et. a., Nature Commun 13, 4014 (2022)). These pinholes appear due to challenges in preparing clean graphene covered surfaces, which are common across most studies to date. The controlled introduction of defects in graphene provides a means to control the synthesis by initiating growth at well defined locations, and the ability to extend the synthesis to use substrates that have nonpolar bonding, such as graphene-covered silicon and germanium.

We then demonstrated two applications of remote epitaxy. First, remote epitaxy provides an etch-free method for synthesizing single crystalline membranes of new materials, since the films can be exfoliated from graphene. Using membranes of the Heusler compounds GdPtSb and GdAuGe, we showed that large strains and strain gradients can induce ferrimagnetism (D. Du, et. al. Nature Commun 12, 2494 (2021)) and superconductivity. This opens new opportunities for tuning and discovery of new materials properties via strain. Second, we showed that monolayer graphene is an excellent solid state diffusion barrier, by quantifying the temperature-dependent diffusion coefficient of the transition metal manganese through graphene (P. Strohbeen, et. al., ACS AMI 13, 35 (2021)). Graphene’s ability to act as an atomically thin, epitaxial diffusion barrier may enable new epitaxial heterostructures that consist of materials that are otherwise chemically incompatible with one another.

Broader impacts. We developed new science modules that were disseminated to the general public, both virtually and in person. In one activity, students build a working model of an atomic force microscope using Legos. We posted video instructions of this activity on the UW Madison MRSEC YouTube channel (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l62_Ib-rjU0) so that families could conduct the activity safely at home during covid-19. In collaboration with science teachers from Wright Middle School (Madison, WI) and Glen Hills Middle School (Milwaukee), we also developed activities on magnetic materials and growth of ferroelectric Rochelle salt crystals. These activities were refined during in class visits with students at Wright and Glen Hills, and instructions are posted on the UW-Madison MRSEC Education Group website (https://education.mrsec.wisc.edu/). Parts of these activities have also been included at the annual Wisconsin Science Festival and the Engineering EXPO, which serves students and the general public across the state of Wisconsin.

 


Last Modified: 06/24/2023
Modified by: Jason Kawasaki
